Problem:
Consider a linear transformation given by a matrix \( M \) in a vector space and its effect on the vector \( x \). The transformation is then followed by an integral transformation represented by \( \mathcal{L} \{ x(t) \} \), which is the Laplace transform of the vector function \( x(t) \).

If a matrix \( N \) is applied as an intervention to \( x(t) \) at time \( t_1 \), resulting in \( Nx(t) \) before applying \( M \), will \( \mathcal{L} \{ M(Nx(t)) \} \) be the same as \( MN \mathcal{L} \{ x(t) \} \)?
Explanation: Applying \( N \) first still results in a linear combination, and thus \( M \) and \( N \) can be merged into a single transformation before applying the Laplace transform. As both operations are linear, \( \mathcal{L} \{ MNx(t) \} = MN \mathcal{L} \{ x(t) \}.
